name: Radiation-Induced Brachial Plexopathy
chief_complaint: Severe pain and weakness in my right arm, with tingling and numbness that's getting worse over time
physical_findings: Positive Tinel's sign at supraclavicular fossa
Muscle fasciculations in deltoid and biceps

lab_results.MRI: Fibrosis and scarring of brachial plexus with nerve root thickening

treatment: Nerve sheath injections with local anesthetic/steroid
Pregabalin or gabapentin for neuropathic pain
prognosis: Guarded - typically progressive with incomplete recovery. Early intervention may slow progression but complete functional restoration is uncommon. Quality of life focus becomes primary in advanced cases.
description: A delayed complication of radiation therapy (typically 6 months to 20 years post-treatment) causing progressive fibrosis and demyelination of the brachial plexus. Most common after treatment for breast cancer, lymphoma, or lung cancer when the plexus was in the radiation field. Pathophysiology involves microvascular damage, axonal degeneration, and perineural fibrosis leading to both motor and sensory deficits.
risk_factors: Younger age at time of radiation
